items.synopsis: The independent tribunal that sets politician pay has determined to give federal MPs a 4 per cent pay rise, saying previous pay increases have been conservative.

image.altText: Nestory Irankunda injury

items.synopsis: A soccer referee who is also a cardiac expert describes the moments in which he rushed to help Adelaide United young gun Nestory Irankunda, who hit his head and appeared to start choking during an alarming on-field incident.

title.children: 'Something didn't look right': The referee who rushed to the rescue of an A-League star

image.altText: A woman in a sea of protesters holds a placard that reads "Not all men but too many"

items.synopsis: The women of the World Cup displayed nothing but merit. Extraordinary feats of skill. Flawless sportsmanship. Good behaviour on and off the pitch. They generated millions of new eyeballs for the beautiful game. And yet, they were overshadowed again and again by second-rate blokes, writes Annabel Crabb.

title.children: It's a classic tale of meritorious women overshadowed by second-rate blokes

image.altText: Linda Burney, standing in front of a group of people, holds a press conference outside with gum trees behind her

items.synopsis: Australia's most senior Indigenous politician has broken her silence about her speech, having faced a campaign of whispers about her health.

title.children: 'My voice has changed': Linda Burney breaks silence amid whisper campaign

image.altText: A composite image shows the three marines in side-by-side images

items.synopsis: The pilot, crew chief and squadron executive officer have been identified as the three US marines killed in Sunday's Osprey crash on Melville Island in the Northern Territory.

title.children: US marines killed in Osprey crash on Tiwi Islands identified

image.altText: Osprey military aircraft taking off from landing helicopter assault vessel.

items.synopsis: The V-22 Osprey has recorded more than 50 fatalities in accidents over the past three decades. On Sunday, the aircraft's death toll grew again.

title.children: Dubbed 'the Widowmaker' after a series of deadly accidents, why is the Osprey still in use?

image.altText: A woman holding a TEMU bag

items.synopsis: A flashy new online shopping app has been bombarding Australians on social media. While some see it as the saviour of China's economy, not everyone is convinced.

title.children: Are you getting a lot of ads for TEMU? The Chinese retailer is coming for Amazon – and it might win

items.synopsis: Many of us are now dressed head to toe in plastic thanks to the invention of cheap and durable textiles like polyester. But the extent of the environmental impact from these garments might surprise you — we've tracked the life cycle of a polyester top from an oil field, through to when you chuck it in the bin.

title.children: Gym clothes, party dresses, work clothes — most of us are wearing plastic. What goes into making a polyester T-shirt?

image.altText: Woman holding baby with head turned away

items.synopsis: Essie Mitchell first spoke to her GP about a lump in her breast when she was 22. But it took 11 years and three more visits before her cancer was finally picked up, by which time it was too late to operate.

title.children: Mum's devastating diagnosis comes too late despite years of tests

image.altText: Cooking on a gas stove

items.synopsis: Experts say getting households and businesses that can easily disconnect from gas is key to meeting emission reduction targets.

title.children: New home gas bans will lead to energy source's 'death spiral', experts say

image.altText: Eminem stands on stage dressed in all black with his arm raised in the air.

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happened.

title.children: Eminem calls for US presidential candidate to stop using his music, London's clean air zone to extend to entire city. Catch up with The Loop

image.altText: A smiling man wearing a suit embraces a woman wearing a football uniform

image.altText: Tails of Qantas and Virgin Australia aircraft

items.synopsis: Local stocks rise in early trade and the bosses of Virgin and Qantas are at loggerheads on a decision to block extra flights by Qatar Airways. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX makes gains, Virgin calls for rethink on extra Qatar flights

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The federal government needs to come clean and confirm who was responsible for the final decision to reject Qatar Airways' bid for an additional 21 weekly flights in Australia, says Flight Centre CEO Graham Turner. The fall out from the rejection has been simmering for days, and Assistant Treasurer Stephen Jones telling the AFR that the rejection was in the national interest and would keep Qantas profitable on Monday only reignited the debate. Speaking to the ABC's senior business correspondent Peter Ryan, Mr Turner said the federal government needs to be up front about who ultimately signed off on vetoing Qatar's bid. "I believe the recommendation from the Department of Transport to the minister, Catherine King, was that it be allowed," he told The World Today. "But the story is that it was someone above her that basically had a captain's call, presumably the Prime Minister. "So it'd be interesting to know: who actually made the call, who made the decision, what the recommendation was, and what was the reason for it? "Because these are questions that [have] just not been answered yet." He said people deserve an explanation to understand what was behind the government's decision making process as they face expensive airfares when booking flights. "A lot of people, a lot of industries, you know, relatively small industries in tourism and travel have been negatively affected by this, [they're seeing] nothing of the relatively expensive airfares that we still have, because there's not enough capacity for the demand at the moment. So airfares are going to stay up ," he said. Mr Turner also believes the issue could end up "blowing up on the government". "I think it could, if they can't give, what their rationale was, what the reason was, who made the decision and why," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Flight Centre CEO says government needs to come clean about Qatar Airways decision

(Supplied: Thomas Pawson)
He said people deserve an explanation to understand what was behind the government's decision making process as they face expensive airfares when booking flights.
"A lot of people, a lot of industries, you know, relatively small
industries in tourism and travel have been negatively affected by this
, [they're seeing] nothing of the relatively expensive airfares that we still have, because there's not enough capacity for the demand at the moment. So
airfares are going to stay up
," he said.
Mr Turner also believes the issue could end up "blowing up on the government".
"I think it could, if they can't give, what their rationale was, what the reason was, who made the decision and why," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Flight Centre boss Graham Turner has described the decision by the federal government to veto the bid by Qatar Airways to double its flights into Australia as one that that has "no logic" behind it. In July it was revealed that Transport Minister Catherine King had rejected Qatar's application for 21 additional flights into Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane per week, on top of its existing 28 weekly flights into Australia's major airports. Yesterday, the Australian Financial Review published comments from Assistant Treasurer Stephen Jones, who explained the government's decision to block the extra Qatar flights was in the national interest and would help keep Qantas profitable. During a Senate committee hearing in Melbourne yesterday, Qantas boss Alan Joyce denied twisting the government's arm on rejecting Qatar's proposal, but Mr Turner told The World Today the reasoning doesn't stack up, because there is a need for flight capacity to increase. "There's no logic to it, and it is a bit of a worry because we have more demand than capacity ," he told the ABC's senior business correspondent Peter Ryan. "So any extra capacity that certainly for our industry is very important. "It was clearly not in the national interest as far as I can see. "You could argue that it could have been in Qantas's interests, it certainly wasn't in Virgin's interest because they have a codeshare relationship with Qatar, so I just don't think it was an argument that held any water ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'No logic' to rejecting Qatar Airways' flight bid, says Flight Centre boss

children.content: Had the bid been approved, Qatar Airways would have operated 49 flights weekly from Australia.
(ABC News: Tom Lowrey)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's still profit-reporting season, and Star Entertainment has released its results this morning. Star Entertainment is the largest casino operator in Australia, with venues in Sydney and  Queensland and a large property portfolio. It's posted a statutory net loss after tax of $2.44 billion for the full-year 2023, due to an impairment charge of $2.48 billion. Significant items of $2.82 billion include: Non-cash impairment of The Star Sydney, The Star Gold Coast and Treasury Brisbane ($2.17 billion) Ongoing regulatory and legal costs ($595 million) Debt restructuring costs ($54 million) and, Redundancy costs ($16 million) The group's normalised net profit after tax was $41 million, a turnaround from a loss of $33 million a year earlier. Significant items are excluded from the normalised results. The group's normalised EBITDA was $317 million, up from $235 million a year earlier.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Star Entertainment posts statutory net loss of $2.44 billion
